thread.title: Arpaio says he can't recall advice on court order
thread.title_full: Arpaio says he can't recall advice on court order

title: Arpaio says he can't recall advice on court order
text:
Arpaio says he can't recall advice on court order Sheriff Joe Arpaio's by-now-familiar court-induced amnesia was on display during his testimony Thursday in his contempt of court hearing Post to Facebook Arpaio says he can't recall advice on court order Sheriff Joe Arpaio's by-now-familiar court-induced amnesia was on display during his testimony Thursday in his contempt of court hearing  //12ne.ws/1Rx6G2a   Join the Conversation To   Arpaio says he can't recall advice on court order   10:03 p.m. MST October 8, 2015 Sheriff Joe Arpaio says he never asked anyone to look into the judge overlooking his case. KPNX Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio (Photo: 12 News) 
PREVIOUS : Arpaio continue testimony in court 
Arpaio was questioned more than a dozen times about whether he remembered his attorney's advice on how to obey a a federal judge's order to stop enforcing federal immigration law. 
The sheriff's answers ranged from "I don't recall," used several times, to "I don't understand sometimes what lawyers say and their legal terms." 
Last week, former Arpaio attorney Tim Casey testified that he told Arpaio he couldn't turn illegal immigrants over to anyone -- he could either arrest them or release them. 
Arpaio came up with a so-called "backup plan" of dropping off illegal immigrants with the Border Patrol. 
The sheriff faces potential criminal contempt charges for ignoring that court order and others stemming from his 8-year-old racial-profiling case in federal court. 
MORE : MCSO employee: Arpaio pet project was "odd" 
Arpaio has already admitted to disobeying the judge's orders. The question before Federal Judge G. Murray Snow is whether he did it intentionally. If that's the case, the sheriff could face criminal contempt charges. 
Also Thursday, Arpaio again denied the most explosive revelations during the contempt hearings -- that Arpaio investigated Judge Snow. 
Court testimony and documents suggest Arpaio used a reputed con artist named Dennis Montgomery to get information that could toss Snow off the case. 
Arpaio's attorney, John Masterson, quoted the sheriff Thursday as having said, "Even the worst guys come up with the best information." 
But Arpaio testified that he believed Montgomery's information showed the U.S. Department of Justice or the CIA was tapping his phone as well as others' phones. He also said it showed activity related to identity. 
Under questioning by Masterson, Arpaio repeatedly denied he had ordered any subordinates to investigate the judge. 
The hearings resume Friday morning and then next Tuesday and Wednesday. Snow said he hoped to wrap up the hearings by the end of the month.  //12ne.ws/1Rx6G2a TOP VIDEOS
